diagnoses.name: Brain Arteriovenous Malformation (AVM)
diagnoses.description: An abnormal connection between arteries and veins in the brain, leading to various neurological symptoms, including difficulty focusing vision and potentially contributing to dysautonomia.

diagnoses.name: Von Hippel-Lindau Disease
diagnoses.description: A genetic disorder causing the growth of tumors in parts of the body rich with blood vessels and can lead to arteriovenous malformations, dyspepsia due to pancreatic or renal cysts, and other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Hereditary Hemorrhagic Telangiectasia
diagnoses.description: A genetic disorder that leads to the development of abnormal blood vessels, including arteriovenous malformations in various organs, which might indirectly cause or exacerbate symptoms like dyspepsia or lymphadenitis.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia Type 1
diagnoses.description: A disorder causing tumors in endocrine glands and can include symptoms like dyspepsia due to peptic ulcers and dysfunction in the autonomous nervous system.

diagnoses.name: Neurofibromatosis
diagnoses.description: A genetic disorder that causes tumors to form on nerve tissue, potentially leading to arteriovenous malformations and neurological symptoms like difficulty focusing vision.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.description: A bacterial infection spread by ticks that can cause a wide range of symptoms, including dysautonomia, lymphadenitis, and vision difficulties, especially in the later stages.

diagnoses.name: Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease (GERD)
diagnoses.description: A long-term condition where stomach acid comes up from the stomach into the esophagus, causing dyspepsia. It doesn’t directly cause AVMs or lymphadenitis but can be present simultaneously.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease that affects multiple organs but most commonly the lungs and lymph nodes, potentially leading to lymphadenitis and other symptoms if it affects the autonomic nervous system or gastrointestinal tract.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that can affect any part of the body, including the nervous system (causing dysautonomias), digestive system (causing dyspepsia), and immune system (leading to lymphadenitis).

diagnoses.name: Behcet's Disease
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder causing blood vessel inflammation throughout the body, which can lead to symptoms like dyspepsia and possibly vision problems, although it’s less commonly associated with arteriovenous malformations.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.rationale: SLE can present with alopecia, lymphadenopathy, and can lead to infertility. Nervous system involvement might mimic pseudoseizures.

diagnoses.name: Behcet's Disease
diagnoses.rationale: Characterized by vasculitis, Behcet's can lead to aneurysms, and its broad systemic involvement can contribute to symptoms like pseudo-seizures.

diagnoses.name: Polyarteritis Nodosa (PAN)
diagnoses.rationale: PAN is a systemic vasculitis that can cause aneurysms, and systemic symptoms could explain alopecia, and lymphadenopathy.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.rationale: HIV can lead to generalized lymphadenopathy, alopecia due to medication or secondary infections, infertility, and rare neurological complications that might present as pseudoseizures.

diagnoses.name: Antiphospholipid Syndrome
diagnoses.rationale: This autoimmune condition can lead to thrombosis which might indirectly cause aneurysms, and it can also present with pseudoseizures. It can affect fertility through multiple miscarriages.

diagnoses.name: Lupus Anticoagulant-Hypoprothrombinemia Syndrome
diagnoses.rationale: Though rare, it can present with symptoms similar to antiphospholipid syndrome and involve blood vessels, potentially causing aneurysms, and affect various systems including fertility.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.rationale: Sarcoidosis features granulomas that can affect any organ system, potentially causing lymphadenopathy, and neurological manifestations similar to pseudoseizures. It can occasionally cause fertility issues and alopecia.

diagnoses.name: Lymphoma
diagnoses.rationale: Lymphoma, specifically non-Hodgkin lymphoma, can cause widespread lymphadenopathy, and certain treatments might cause alopecia and fertility issues. Nervous system involvement could lead to seizures.

diagnoses.name: Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome (vascular type)
diagnoses.rationale: Though primarily affecting connective tissue, vascular Ehlers-Danlos can lead to aneurysms and affect multiple systems, potentially relating to other symptoms indirectly.

diagnoses.name: Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS)
diagnoses.rationale: PCOS is a common cause of infertility and can be associated with alopecia due to hormonal imbalances. It doesn't explain all symptoms directly but could be a concurrent condition.

diagnoses: Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV) / Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome (AIDS)
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS Syndrome)

diagnoses.name: Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy
diagnoses.description: A temporary heart condition that often results from stress and presents similarly to a heart attack, with no coronary artery blockage.

diagnoses.name: Bleeding Disorders
diagnoses.description: Conditions that affect the way your blood normally clots, leading to excessive bleeding, which can be due to a variety of underlying conditions.

diagnoses.name: Dyslipidemia
diagnoses.description: An abnormal amount of lipids (e.g., cholesterol and/or fat) in the blood, which can lead to cardiovascular disease.

diagnoses.name: Lymphadenopathy
diagnoses.description: Swelling of the lymph nodes, which can be caused by a variety of conditions, from infections to malignancies.

diagnoses.name: Blepharospasm
diagnoses.description: A condition causing the eyelids to involuntarily blink or close, often due to stress, fatigue, or other neurological conditions.

diagnoses.name: Vitamin Deficiency
diagnoses.description: Deficiencies in vitamins, such as Vitamin C (scurvy) leading to easy bleeding, or Vitamin D affecting the immune system, could explain a combination of symptoms like easy bleeding and lymphadenopathy.

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune Disorders
diagnoses.description: Diseases such as lupus or rheumatoid arthritis, where the immune system attacks healthy cells, can cause a wide range of symptoms including dyslipidemia and lymphadenopathy.

diagnoses.name: Infectious Diseases
diagnoses.description: Certain infections can cause lymphadenopathy, easy bleeding, and potentially trigger phenomena similar to Takotsubo cardiomyopathy through stress on the body.

diagnoses.name: Neurological Conditions
diagnoses.description: Some neurological disorders could simultaneously cause or contribute to symptoms of blepharospasm and cardiomyopathy, reflecting complex interplay between the nervous and cardiovascular systems.

diagnoses.name: Hematological Malignancies
diagnoses.description: Cancers of the blood or bone marrow, such as lymphoma or leukemia, can lead to symptoms like lymphadenopathy, easy bleeding, and possibly dyslipidemia through various mechanisms.

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune diseases
diagnoses.rationale: This group of disorders, where the body's immune system attacks its own cells, can cause a wide variety of symptoms across different organ systems, including vulvodynia and lymphadenopathy. Hyperferritinemia can also be present in autoimmune conditions as part of an inflammatory response.

diagnoses.name: Stress-related disorders
diagnoses.rationale: Stress and psychological factors can significantly impact physical health, potentially contributing to conditions like takotsubo cardiomyopathy, which is often triggered by acute emotional or physical stress, and obsessive-compulsive behavior. Stress can also exacerbate symptoms of vulvodynia.

diagnoses.name: Infectious diseases
diagnoses.rationale: Certain infections can cause lymphadenopathy and may indirectly contribute to or exacerbate symptoms of vulvodynia through chronic inflammation or immune dysregulation. Hyperferritinemia can occur in severe infections as part of the acute phase response.

diagnoses.name: Neoplastic diseases
diagnoses.rationale: Cancer and other neoplasms can cause lymphadenopathy and hyperferritinemia, and stress associated with chronic illness might contribute to psychological conditions like obsessive-compulsive behavior.

diagnoses.name: Endocrine disorders
diagnoses.rationale: Hormonal imbalances can contribute to psychological conditions and may indirectly affect cardiovascular health, possibly triggering conditions like takotsubo cardiomyopathy in susceptible individuals.

diagnoses.name: Hematological disorders
diagnoses.rationale: Conditions affecting the blood, like hemochromatosis, could lead to hyperferritinemia. Lymphadenopathy can also be seen in hematological diseases.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Pain Syndromes
diagnoses.rationale: Conditions characterized by chronic pain, such as vulvodynia, can have a significant psychological burden and may be linked with the development of stress-related disorders and obsessive-compulsive behavior.

diagnoses.name: Psychiatric disorders
diagnoses.rationale: Obsessive-compulsive behavior can be a manifestation of underlying psychiatric conditions, which can also influence the perception and severity of physical symptoms like vulvodynia.

diagnoses.name: Cardiomyopathy and cardiovascular diseases
diagnoses.rationale: Takotsubo cardiomyopathy is a specific type of heart condition triggered by stress, including emotional or physical stress, suggesting a link with psychological health conditions.

diagnoses.name: Immunodeficiency conditions
diagnoses.rationale: Individuals with weakened immune systems may present with recurrent or chronic lymphadenopathy and are at increased risk for certain infections that could exacerbate or contribute to the other listed symptoms.

diagnoses: Inflammatory Bowel Disease (Crohn's disease and Ulcerative Colitis)
Inflammatory bowel disease (e.g., Crohn's disease, Ulcerative colitis)
Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD) with Acute Lower Respiratory Infection
Peanut or other severe food allergies
Common cold with secondary bacterial infection

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A condition where poor blood flow to the brain results in cell death, causing symptoms such as weakness, headache, and aphasia.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA)
diagnoses.description: Often called a minibar, a TIA presents similar to a stroke but symptoms are temporary, typically resolving within 24 hours.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: An abnormal growth of cells within the brain, which can cause headaches, weakness, and language disturbances.

diagnoses.name: Migraine with Aura
diagnoses.description: A type of headache accompanied by visual disturbances or other sensory changes, which may sometimes include weakness or language disturbances.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that affects the brain and spinal cord, leading to weakness, speech disturbances, and other neurological symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Encephalitis
diagnoses.description: Inflammation of the brain, often due to infection, causing headache, fever, confusion, and in severe cases, speech disturbances and weakness.

diagnoses.name: Brain Abscess
diagnoses.description: A collection of pus that develops in the brain due to infection, which can cause headaches, speech problems, and weakness.

diagnoses.name: Meningitis
diagnoses.description: Inflammation of the brain and spinal cord membranes, typically caused by an infection. Symptoms include headache, fever, and in severe cases, confusion and aphasia.

diagnoses.name: Epilepsy
diagnoses.description: A neurological disorder marked by sudden recurrent episodes of sensory disturbance, loss of consciousness, or convulsions, associated with abnormal electrical activity in the brain. It can sometimes present with postictal language and motor disturbances.

diagnoses.name: Primary Progressive Aphasia
diagnoses.description: A form of cognitive impairment that involves a progressive loss of language function, including speaking, reading, writing, and understanding language, which may be accompanied by other neurological symptoms such as weakness or headaches in some cases.

diagnoses: Vasculitis (e.g., Polyarteritis Nodosa, Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis)
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS) Syndrome
Vasculitis (e.g., microscopic polyangiitis, eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis)
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS) syndrome
Chronic Hepatitis B and C Infections
Rheumatoid arthritis with secondary Sjogren's syndrome

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.rationale: SLE is a chronic autoimmune disease that can affect various parts of the body, including joints, skin, kidneys, blood cells, brain, heart, and lungs. It may present with a wide range of manifestations, including cranial neuropathy, hemolytic anemia, oral ulcers, and pericarditis, which are common in SLE.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA)
diagnoses.rationale: Though primarily known as a chronic inflammatory disorder affecting the joints, RA can have systemic manifestations. It can lead to Felty's syndrome, characterized by rheumatoid arthritis, splenomegaly, and granulocytopenia, and can feature hemolytic anemia. RA may also cause pericarditis and oral ulcers, but cranial neuropathy is less common.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease (MCTD)
diagnoses.rationale: MCTD is a rare autoimmune disorder that displays clinical features of SLE, scleroderma, and polymyositis, including symptoms such as cranial neuropathy, hemolytic anemia, oral ulcers, and pericarditis, making it a potential diagnosis.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.rationale: Sjögren's is primarily characterized by dry eyes and dry mouth, but it is also associated with systemic features. Cranial neuropathy might occur due to the disease's neurological manifestations. Though less common, systemic involvement can include hemolytic anemia and pericarditis, and oral ulcers may also be present.

diagnoses.name: Behçet's Disease
diagnoses.rationale: This is a rare disorder causing blood vessel inflammation throughout the body. Key features include mouth sores, eye inflammation, skin rashes, and genital sores. While oral ulcers are a hallmark, it can also lead to various systemic complications, potentially explaining the other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Vasculitis
diagnoses.rationale: Vasculitis encompasses a group of disorders that cause blood vessel inflammation, leading to multiple systemic symptoms. Depending on the subtype, symptoms can include hemolytic anemia, pericarditis, and possibly cranial neuropathy due to nerve involvement. Oral ulcers can occur in certain vasculitides like Behçet's disease.

diagnoses.name: Infectious Mononucleosis
diagnoses.rationale: Caused by the Epstein-Barr virus, this infection can present with hemolytic anemia, oral ulcers, and pericarditis as atypical manifestations. Cranial neuropathy is rare but has been documented.

diagnoses.name: Lupus-like Syndrome
diagnoses.rationale: Drug-induced lupus or other lupus-like syndromes can mimic the clinical presentation of systemic lupus erythematosus, including symptoms such as hemolytic anemia, oral ulcers, and pericarditis. Cranial neuropathy might be observed in severe cases.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.rationale: Sarcoidosis is a systemic granulomatous disease that can affect any organ system. Cranial neuropathy may occur if the neurological system is involved. It can also present with symptoms such as pericarditis, though hemolytic anemia and oral ulcers are less commonly associated.

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune Hemolytic Anemia (AIHA)
diagnoses.rationale: While AIHA primarily involves hemolytic anemia, it can be associated with other autoimmune disorders that may present symptoms like oral ulcers and pericarditis. Cranial neuropathy could occur in the context of a broader autoimmune process.

diagnoses: Evans Syndrome (Autoimmune Hemolytic Anemia with Immune Thrombocytopenia)
